Award.AwardTitle: Terraces, large phylogenetic trees, and trait evolution
Award.AbstractNarration:
Scientists are using massive data sets of DNA sequences and new computing technologies to place all 2 million biological species into a grand synthesis, the evolutionary tree of life. Evolutionary trees permit predictions about the traits that organisms possess based on traits present in closely related species. This has important practical benefits in areas like medicine, conservation biology, and crop improvement. Although building small trees from DNA from just a few genes is straightforward, many obstacles remain to scaling up this effort to all life. One of the most serious is missing data. Under some conditions, even a few gene sequences missing for a handful of species can produce evolutionary trees that lack detailed resolution. This grant is a collaboration among biologists, mathematicians and computer scientists to understand the circumstances in which missing data cause problems, and to develop methods to overcome them. The research will generate mathematically provable results and new software to help biologists build more reliable large evolutionary trees. These products will be tested with real world data sampled from flowering plants, one of the most diverse branches of the tree of life, with over 250,000 species. The high quality evolutionary trees generated because of this project will provide a societal need by providing clear evolutionary knowledge to inform conservation planning and prioritization. The research team will organize a workshop for graduate students around the country to train them in the use of these new tools, and will develop educational materials for high school students involving computer visualization of the tree of life.


The construction of very large phylogenetic trees from sequence data mined from databases can be challenging because of the recently discovered problem of terraces--potentially vast regions in "tree space" in which all trees have precisely the same optimality score due to missing data. This research focuses first on developing a better conceptual understanding of four problematic impacts of terraces on large tree construction: (i) increased ambiguity, (ii) biased confidence assessments obtained from bootstrapping or Bayesian posterior probabilities, (iii) impediments to tree search algorithms, and (iv) downstream effects on comparative inferences that rely on trees. Next, the research will develop analytical methods and software implementations to overcome these problems. Finally, it will test these new methods by applying them to 27 large-scale phylogenies newly constructed within flowering plants, each with 1000+ species, examining trait evolution, as an exemplar of downstream comparative inference, in a subset of these.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our NSF grant funded research into the challenging problem of reconstructing very large phylogenetic trees--the genealogies of species in the tree of life. Like many problems in modern biology, inferring phylogenetic trees from data faces a number of computational challenges, because the number of possible answers for a given set of data is so large. Our work focused on one especially troubling problem having to do with the inevitable presence of missing information in data sets based on sequencing only parts of the genomes of species. Previously, we had shown that this missing data leads to "terraces" in the space of possible solutions, where every tree seems equally likely to be correct. Our goals in the grant funded research were to understand better the mathematical and algorithm-engineering issues involved in overcoming this problem, developing software solutions, characterizing better the extent of the problem in real data, and engaging in educational activities to communicate both the problem and our results.

 

As a result of this work, we improved understanding of the theoretical issues underlying terraces and established an even broader set of conditions under which terraces could emerge. We developed a software package called Terraphy to let users characterize the properties of terraces for their data set and come to a better understanding of their potential impact. We surveyed published studies to summarize the extent and size of terraces in work that has already been undertaken in the field and found a range of answers, from studies with no terraces to some studies with astronomically large terraces. Finally, we undertook two main outreach activities. One was to hold a workshop for 20 graduate students from around the country (with some international participants as well), who work with phylogenetic trees in their own research. There we provided background material, shared our findings and gave software tutorials. The other activity was development of a free app for mobile devices, called Phlora, which displays large phylogenetic trees and associated image data. Users, whether scientists or the general public interested in biodiversity, can use this to organize their own image collections.

 

Among its many applications, large phylogenetic trees play an important role in biomedical and public health settings, especially in relation to epidemiology and infectious disease transmission. We expect our work aimed at understanding the impact of missing data in building these phylogenies will have the downstream effect of improving the reliability of such efforts (or, minimally, better characterizing their reliability).
